personnel.notes: Standard Italian binary infantry division strength per TM E 30-420, without Militia legion. Savona Division in Libya Q1 1941 likely at 80-90% strength due to desert conditions.

trucks.notes: Mix of Fiat, Lancia, and other Italian trucks

equipment.notes: Equipment levels based on standard Italian binary division TO&E per TM E 30-420 fig. 5. Desert conditions likely reduced vehicle availability by 10-20%. Artillery regiment lost during British advance winter 1940-41 per Order of Battle document.

fuel_reserves.notes: Estimated based on ~160 vehicles at 20L/vehicle/day. Italian logistics in Libya severely constrained by British naval interdiction.

ammunition_stocks.notes: Based on Italian Army standard 3 UF (Unit of Fire) for division. Desert supply lines problematic Q1 1941.

water_supply.notes: Desert operations require 3L/man/day minimum. Water critical constraint in Libyan operations.

food_rations.notes: Standard Italian divisional ration scale. Field bakery operational.

operational_radius.notes: Limited by animal transport and truck fuel capacity. Most units horse-drawn. Desert terrain reduces effective range.

supply_logistics.supply_notes: Division in Libya faces severe supply constraints Q1 1941. British naval dominance limits sea transport from Italy. Fuel and ammunition stocks below operational requirements. Division destroyed November 1941 per Order of Battle document, artillery regiment lost winter 1940-41 during Operation Compass.

temperature.notes: Coastal Libya winter temperatures. Mild days, cool nights.

terrain_conditions.trafficability: Good for wheeled vehicles on tracks, difficult off-road
terrain_conditions.notes: Libyan coastal desert. Firm sand and gravel, sparse vegetation. Via Balbia coastal road main supply artery.

operational_impact.health_factors: Moderate - water shortage risk, respiratory issues from dust
operational_impact.notes: Desert environment favors mechanized forces. Italian reliance on animal transport disadvantageous. Water scarcity critical constraint. British air superiority limits daylight movement.

historical_notes.combat_history: 55th Savona Division deployed to Libya before Italian entry into WWII (10 June 1940). Participated in initial operations against British Egypt. Engaged in defensive operations during Operation Compass (December 1940 - February 1941). Lost artillery regiment during British winter advance 1940-41. Division destroyed November 1941 during Operation Crusader.
historical_notes.status_1941q1: Engaged in defensive operations following Operation Compass. Reduced strength, artillery regiment lost. Attempting reconstitution in Libya Q1 1941.

sources.title: TM E 30-420: Handbook on Italian Military Forces
sources.notes: US War Department technical manual. Detailed TO&E for Italian infantry division (binary type). Figure 5 shows complete organization with personnel and equipment breakdowns.

sources.title: Order of Battle of the Italian Army, July 1943
sources.notes: Identifies 55th Savona Division, states it was in Libya 10 June 1940, lost artillery regiment winter 1940-41, destroyed November 1941. Lists 15th and 16th Savona Infantry Regiments, 12th Sila Artillery Regiment.

metadata.notes: Complete v3.0.0 schema extraction from Tier 1 primary sources (TM E 30-420, US Military Intelligence OOB). Division TO&E based on standard Italian binary infantry division organization. Q1 1941 status reflects post-Operation Compass reduced strength with artillery regiment lost. Supply/logistics data estimated based on Italian Army standards and Libyan operational constraints. Weather/environment data for coastal Libya winter conditions.
gaps: Commander name not identified in sources for Q1 1941
Exact vehicle types and distribution not specified
Precise fuel and ammunition stocks - estimated from standard scales
Engineer battalion exact strength not specified - estimated from typical organization
